As states begin sending out vote by mail ballots for the 2020 presidential election, misinformation and widespread claims of fraud are ramping up ahead of Election Day.

Photos showing a large amount of envelopes claiming to be "mail-in ballots found in a dumpster in California" were shared online, where social media users accused Sonoma County officials in Petaluma, California, of discarding ballots.
“This is why we cant Trust a Mail in Election,” wrote Joey Saladino, host of a daily conservative commentary news show. His post now has over 2,100 shares and over 600 reactions.

The notion appears to have originated on The Gateway Pundit. A reader in California sent to the site the photos of the alleged unopened ballots found in a dumpster. “We are working to verify. Big if true,” The Gateway Pundit reported.

The Gateway Pundit then updated the post: “According to a state source California does nto (SIC) mail out ballots until October fifth and those already have return addresses.” Other updates were also noted at the bottom of the story, such as a report from KTVU that clarified the ballots were from the 2018 election and an image of a 2018 California ballot. After these notes, however, Gateway Pundit writes, "This does not explain why the ballots in the trash are still sealed."
The updated headline states: "California Man Finds THOUSANDS of Unopened Ballots in Garbage Dumpster — Workers Quickly Try to Cover Them Up — County Says Returned Ballots from 2018?"

The claim also gained traction after being shared by BlazeTV host Elijah Schaffer in a tweet — which has since been deleted — according to the Sacramento Bee and Snopes. Schaffer tweeted the photos, stating they were anonymously sent to him by a Republic Services landfill in Sonoma County.
“SHOCKING: 1,000+ mail-in-ballots found in a dumpster in California,” Schaffer had tweeted, according to the Sacramento Bee. “Big if true."
In a Twitter message to USA TODAY, Schaffer said he never made the claim that the photos were of 2020 ballots being illegally thrown away.

"I didn’t say the images were from this year, asked for others to clarify if it was real or not in the thread. So you can’t really fact check a claim that was never made," Schaffer wrote, adding that he used "journalistic standards to inquire more information from the general public."
However, the claim had already gone viral across social media platforms, many citing the link to the Gateway Pundit story.
USA TODAY reached out to Saladino and The Gateway Pundit for comment.
Fact check: What's true and what's false about voting by mail in 2020
The photos show empty envelopes from 2018 that were legally discarded, according to officials who took to Twitter to debunk the rumors.

"Help us stop a false report," reads a Sept. 25 tweet from Sonoma County. "Someone posted pictures on the web showing empty Vote-by-Mail envelopes from Sonoma County in recycling bins. The pictures are of old empty envelopes from the November 2018 election that were disposed of as allowed by law."
The Election Integrity Project noted on Twitter that "images and stories like these are being used to mislead people about the integrity of the election."

Deva Marie Proto, the county's registrar of voters, told The Press Democrat that the county has not yet sent out mail-in-ballots for the Nov. 3 election. According to Sonoma County's site, ballots will be mailed to voters starting Oct. 5, the same date noted by Gateway Pundit.

The California Secretary of State's site states that "every provisional ballot — whether it is counted or rejected — and provisional ballot envelope is kept by the elections official for a minimum of 22 months for every election in which a candidate for federal office is on the ballot."
Proto said it is Sonoma County's practice to dispose of election materials at the end of the 22-month period, and that mail envelopes and other election material will be shredded in the future.
Fact check: Photo claiming National Park Service gives watermelon to bees is false

The claim that thousands of sealed mail-in ballots were found in a dumpster in California is FALSE, based on our research. Sonoma County officials confirmed that the photos are of old empty envelopes from the November 2018 election and were recycled after the state's mandated 22-month ballot preservation period.
